{{Discrimination sidebar}}
'''Allophilia''' is having a positive attitude towards outgroup members. The outgroup members can be anyone who possesses characteristics that are different from one's own, such as people of different [[Race (human categorization)|races]], [[religion]]s, [[culture]]s, etc. It is a framework for understanding effective intergroup leadership and is conceptualized as a measurable state of mind with tangible consequences.<ref>{{cite news|title= Allophilia—a new framework for understanding effective intergroup leadership|author= Todd Pittinsky|url= http://www.centerforpublicleadership.org/?option=com_content&task=emailform&id=267&itemid=2|newspaper= [[Center for Public Leadership]], [[Harvard Kennedy School]]|access-date= 18 June 2013|url-status= dead|archive-url= https://archive.today/20130620034033/http://www.centerforpublicleadership.org/?option=com_content&task=emailform&id=267&itemid=2|archive-date= 20 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Positive prejudice: Really loving your neighbour |url= http://www.economist.com/node/8859092 |newspaper= [[The Economist]]|date= 15 March 2007 |access-date=18 June 2013}}</ref>
==Terminology== The term ''allophilia'' was coined by [[Harvard]] professor [[Todd Pittinsky|Todd L. Pittinsky]] in 2006, after he was unable to find an antonym for prejudice in any dictionary.<ref>{{cite news |title=Otherly Love: The Law of Dissimilars|author= Ashley Pettus|url= http://harvardmagazine.com/2006/01/the-law-of-dissimilars.html|newspaper= [[Harvard Magazine]] |date=January 2006 |access-date=18 June 2013}}</ref> The term derived from [[Greek language|Greek]] words meaning "liking or love of the other".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Pittinsky |first1=Todd L. |title=A two-dimensional model of intergroup leadership: The case of national diversity |journal=American Psychologist |date=2010 |volume=65 |issue=3 |pages=194–200 |doi=10.1037/a0017329 |pmid=20350018 }}</ref>
==Statistical factors== # affection, # comfort, # engagement, # enthusiasm, # kinship.
The allophilia scale measures each of these factors.<ref>{{cite news |title=Allophilia: Beyond tolerance lies true respect|author= Sheema Khan|url= https://www.theglobeandmail.com/commentary/allophilia-beyond-tolerance-lies-true-respect/article9130024/|newspaper= [[The Globe and Mail]] |date=28 February 2013 |access-date=18 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Pittinsky |first1=T. L. |last2=Rosenthal |first2=S. A. |last3=Montoya |first3=R. M. |year=2011 |chapter=Measuring positive attitudes toward outgroups: Development and validation of the Allophilia Scale |editor1-first=L. R. |editor1-last=Tropp |editor2-first=R. K. |editor2-last=Mallett |title=Moving beyond prejudice reduction: Pathways to positive intergroup relations |pages=41–60 |publisher=American Psychological Association |doi=10.1037/12319-002 }}</ref> It has been adapted and validated to other languages such as Italian and Spanish, also to various settings, such as to measure positive attitude toward people with dementia, younger and older adults.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Alfieri |first1=Sara |last2=Marta |first2=Elena |title=Positive attitudes towards the outgroup: adaptation and validation of the allophilia scale |journal=TPM |date=2011 |volume=18 |issue=2 |pages=99–116 |url=http://www.tpmap.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/18.2.3.pdf |hdl=10807/13381 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Alfieri|first=S.|last2=Marta|first2=E.|date=2011|title=Positive attitudes toward the outgroup: adaptation and validation of the Allophilia scale|journal=Testing, Psychometrics, Methodology in Applied Psychology|volume=18|pages=99–116}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Magallares |first1=Alejandro |last2=Morales |first2=Jose Francisco |title=Spanish adaptation of the Allophilia Scale |journal=Anales de Psicología |date=31 March 2017 |volume=33 |issue=2 |pages=283–291 |doi=10.6018/analesps.33.2.242021 |doi-access=free }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Kinney |first1=Jennifer M |last2=Yamashita |first2=Takashi |last3=Brown |first3=J Scott |title=Measuring positive attitudes toward persons with dementia: A validation of the Allophilia scale |journal=Dementia |date=17 February 2016 |volume=16 |issue=8 |pages=1045–1060 |doi=10.1177/1471301216633247 |pmid=26892304 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Wagner |first1=Lisa S. |last2=Luger |first2=Tana M. |title=Assessing positive attitudes toward older and younger adults |journal=Educational Gerontology |date=20 December 2016 |volume=43 |issue=3 |pages=147–165 |doi=10.1080/03601277.2016.1272890 }}</ref> [[File:Allophilia Scale.svg|thumb|right|340px|Allophilia scale]]
==Prejudice and positive intergroup relations==
The typical remedy for [[prejudice]] is to bring conflicting groups into a state of tolerance. However, tolerance is not the logical antithesis of prejudice, but rather is the midpoint between negative feelings and positive feelings toward others. Allophilia enhancement should serve as complement to prejudice reduction.<ref name="ref3">{{cite journal |last1=Pittinsky |first1=Todd L. |last2=Montoya |first2=R. Matthew |title=Sympathy e symhedonia nelle relazioni intergruppi. Dispiacere empatico e gioia empatica in rapporto a pregiudizio e allofilia |trans-title=Sympathy and symhedonia in intergroup relations: The relationship of empathic sorrow and empathic joy to prejudice and allophilia |language=it |journal=Psicologia sociale |date=2009 |volume=4 |issue=3 |pages=347–364 |doi=10.1482/30689 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Pittinsky |first1=Todd L. |title=Allophilia: Moving beyond Tolerance in the Classroom |journal=Childhood Education |date=June 2009 |volume=85 |issue=4 |pages=212–215 |doi=10.1080/00094056.2009.10523083 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Pittinsky |first1=Todd L. |title=Look Both Ways |journal=Phi Delta Kappan |date=January 2009 |volume=90 |issue=5 |pages=363–364 |doi=10.1177/003172170909000511 }}</ref>
Allophilia predicts positive relationships with outgroup members. For instance, a study in Spain shows that students having higher allophilia had lower social distance toward people with obesity.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Magallares |first1=Alejandro |title=Predictors of Social Distance Toward People with Obesity: The Role of Allophilia |journal=International Review of Social Psychology |date=2 May 2017 |volume=30 |issue=1 |pages=102–110 |doi=10.5334/irsp.110 |doi-access=free }}</ref> Besides, positive experience with outgroup members may increase allophilia, as it is shown in a longitudinal study of a cook's tour in Vietnam. In that study, the participants, who were Americans, reported positive feelings toward Vietnamese mirroring Allophilia facets in nearly 10 years after the event.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Livert |first1=David |title=A Cook's Tour Abroad: Long-Term Effects of Intergroup Contact on Positive Outgroup Attitudes |journal=Journal of Social Issues |date=September 2016 |volume=72 |issue=3 |pages=524–547 |doi=10.1111/josi.12180 }}</ref>
In one study, [[mudita|symhedonia]] (experiencing empathic joy) has been shown to be more closely associated with allophilia, while sympathy (experiencing empathic sorrow) has been shown to be more strongly associated with prejudice.<ref name="ref3"/>
